Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Motivated Engineering Transfers-STEM Talent Expansion Program (METSTEP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project is a collaborative effort between a four-year school (Arizona State University) and five non-metropolitan feeder schools (Arizona Western College, Central Arizona College, Cochise College, Eastern Arizona College, and Mohave Community College). The team is working to significantly increase the number of transfer students, especially women and underrepresented minority students, that graduate in engineering and computer science. In order to accomplish this, they are: 1) providing scholarships to students in the feeder schools and to transfer students at Arizona State University , 2) supporting student outreach activities at the feeder schools, 3) supporting engineering courses at the feeder schools by providing materials, tutoring, local engineering speakers, and tuition scholarships, 4) conducting "Be an Engineer" events at the feeder schools for both students and their parents, 5) providing classes, workshops, and seminars using live broadcast and videotape, 6) providing an engaged community of mentors with extensive experience and commitment for all students, 7) hosting an orientation at Arizona State University for engineering transfer students, 8) managing a center where engineering transfer students can study together and get the support needed to survive, and 9) working with transfer students through a time-tested "career shaping" academic scholarship workshop program. The project is building on an earlier successful program between Arizona State University and a set of metropolitan community colleges with similar goals. Evaluation efforts, involving formative and summative aspects, are being conducted by internal and external evaluators who are developing and monitoring indices for enrollment, persistence, and graduation. Broader impacts include the development and dissemination of models for collaboration between community colleges and four-year schools and the efforts to increase the number of women and minorities in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With funding from an NSF STEP grant, Eastern Arizona College (EAC) partnered with Arizona State University (ASU) and other Arizona community colleges to increase the number of engineering majors, increase the number of students graduating with an associate's degree in engineering, and increase the number of engineering students transferring to a university to pursue a bachelor's degree in engineering.

In the five years prior to the grant only three students had graduated from EAC in engineering. During the grant period from 2010-2015, thirty-three students graduated with an AS degree in Engineering including 1 Native American and 9 Hispanics. EAC witnessed a similar increase in the number of students transferring to a university to pursue a Bachelor's Degree in Engineering.

Over the past 6 years there has been a significant increase in interest and activity within the engineering program. Scholarships provided through the grant have been instrumental in encouraging students to pursue engineering. The number of students declaring engineering as their major increased from 67 in 2009 to a high of 90 in 2013, remaining a healthy 86 in 2014. This increase was even more significant as the college saw an overall decrease in enrollment during this same time frame.

There were many factors that led to these gains. Before the grant, students at our rural community college had limited interaction with the university they hoped to transfer to after attending EAC. As a result of this grant a strong partnership was formed with ASU. Representatives from ASU Engineering visited EAC each semester to inform students about ASU engineering programs and encouraged them to pursue a STEM major. ASU representatives also visited some of the local high schools to encourage students to take appropriate courses in high school that would lead to a STEM major in college. Students from EAC traveled to ASU each semester to visit with ASU Engineering faculty and students. While ASU was one of the partners in this grant, visits were not restricted to ASU. EAC students also traveled to the University of Arizona. Getting students onto the campus of a university was a catalyst in helping them transfer and pursue a Bachelor's Degree in Engineering.

The Engineering Club has been a vital addition to EAC and has helped the engineering students become a cohesive group. In 2015, the Engineering Club designed a trebuchet for EAC's first Sci-Tech Festival. In 2014 engineering students helped EAC with the assessment of the foundation and pipes supporting our existing marquee. Mr. Palmer reached out to a local structural engineer who mentored the Engineering Club and helped them perform required measurements and calculations to certify that the existing foundation and pipes were strong enough to handle the wind load and related stresses of a new electronic sign/marquee. This was an opportunity to introduce our engineering students to a "real world" engineering project. In 2013-2014, the Engineering Club designed and built a T-shirt cannon that was used at football and volleyball games. The Engineering Club also participated with a local engineering firm on a preliminary design of a bridge to carry a water main over the San Simon River. In 2012-2013, the Engineering Club designed and constructed a small wind tunnel, to be used in the Introduction to Engineering class.

In addition to the Sci-Tech Festival, other outreach efforts were conducted to increase awareness of career opportunities in engineering and the transfer pathways available. Participation in Engineering Day more than doubled with the largest ever attendance occurring in 2015 with 145 high school students (75 female and 75 male).
